wordSentence: Each man came out of their acrimonious 200-meter showdown on July 23 with an injured hamstring and a decidedly negative vibe.

My May 19, 1967, memorandum to the president unleashed a storm of controversy.  … It led to tense and acrimonious Senate hearings that pitted me against the Joint Chiefs of Staff and generated rumors they intended to resign en masse.
But considering the momentousness of the issue, the original Darwinian debate was far less acrimonious than might have been expected …
We could tell, however, when debate became more acrimonious than professional, but this was from watching lawyers other than our father.

meanings: unfriendly and aggressive
(used about a country) fighting a war

She was a brigantine, a small two-masted vessel, refitted for belligerent action in the newly created American Navy.

meanings:

pleasant; nice.

warm and canny under the woolen bedcovers, we didn't mind the chilly Scottish nights

The government provided funds to the economically distressed city.
Donations were given to financially distressed families.

meanings: to become smaller or weaker

The town's population is dwindling away.

meanings:
comprehensive in terms of information.

comprehensive

thorough
thoroughgoing
full

relating to encyclopedias or information suitable for an encyclopedia.

his almost encyclopedic knowledge of movies

meanings: to make something worse, especially a disease or problem
wordSentence: The declining retirement security faced by growing numbers of Americans is being exacerbated by increasing longevity and quickly rising health care costs.

… the sway that pack journalism holds on the Beltway press corps persists. The Crowd is never so influential as in the ever-lengthening season of presidential campaigns. The feverish obsessions of the blogosphere have only exacerbated the phenomenon: Now the herd just turns faster in pursuit of some ginned-up "controversy" or faux scandal.
The proposed factory shutdown would only exacerbate our unemployment problems.
His angry comments have exacerbated tensions in the negotiation process.

meanings:
(of a product or commodity) replaceable by another identical item; mutually interchangeable.
"it is by no means the world's only fungible commodity"
wordSentence: since fruits and vegetables are regarded as fungible in this diet, you are allowed a total of five servings of either or both

meanings: (used about phrases, ideas, fashion etc.) boring because it has been used too often
wordSentence: it's hackneyed, but true—the more you save the more you earn

meanings: strange and out of place; not suitable in a particular situation
wordSentence: There is something incongruous about Oslo.
… it would be as incongruous to meet her at the end of a chapter as it would be to see the dawn break in the west …
He ate enormously, with a zest which seemed incongruous with his spare frame.
His outburst seemed incongruous to those who know him well.
there's an incongruous modernism to the actor's performance in this period piece

meanings: able to be used in place of each other without making any difference to the way something works
wordSentence: the concept of interchangeable parts revolutionized the mass production of manufactured goods

meanings: using only a few words to say something
wordSentence: We would rather have a smiling, shape-shifting Democrat we don't trust than a frowning, laconic Republican we trust more.
The closest anyone comes to announcing his destination is a laconic "Guess I'll head on in."
… towards the father—laconic, authoritarian, remote, an immigrant who'd trained in Galicia to be a rabbi but worked in America in a hat factory—their feelings were more confused.
He had a reputation for being laconic.
the sportscaster's color commentary tends to be laconic but very much to the point

meanings: allowing somebody to earn a lot of money
wordSentence: Their success has given Gladwell an active, and extremely lucrative, second career as a public speaker. Much in demand, he is paid in the neighborhood of $40,000 per lecture.

Clubs take care of their star and other best players first, paying them lucrative salaries. By the time they get to the bottom half of the roster, they would not have enough money left to pay veterans worthwhile salaries …
Since the health care industry is lucrative and largely insulated from the usual disciplines of the marketplace, it has been able to absorb an ever-growing fraction of the gross domestic product.

The learned profession of the law was certainly not behind any other learned profession in its Bacchanalian propensities; neither was Mr. Stryver, already fast shouldering his way to a large and lucrative practice, behind his compeers in this particular, any more than in the drier parts of the legal race.

meanings: (especially of a person or their behaviour) having or seeming to have power or authority
(of a book or piece of writing) having great knowledge or understanding

a magisterial biography of Thomas Jefferson that has never been superseded

meanings: difficult and needing a lot of effort
wordSentence: Then everyone was asked, how fairly did you act?, from "extremely unfairly" (1) to "extremely fairly" (7). Next they watched someone else make the assignments, and judged that person's ethics. Selflessness was a virtual no-show: 87 out of 94 people opted for the easy task and gave the next guy the onerous one.

The first hitch occurred when the state education department took a full six months after the new law was adopted to issue 12 pages of onerous rules and regulations governing Arkansas charter schools.
Environmentalism poses stark issues of survival, for humankind and for all those other tribes of creatures over which we have exercised our onerous dominion.

Rap tested well, but early on the promoters said they wouldn't be booking any gangsta rap, a move at least partly designed to calm security concerns during the onerous process of complying with the strict mass-gathering laws enacted in the wake of the 1969 festival.

meanings:

meanings: not as important as the main aim, part, etc. of something

peripheral devices such as modems and scanners

meanings: intended to make somebody angry or upset or to cause an argument

meanings: to say formally that you no longer want to have something or to be connected with something

meanings: (used about a relationship, period of time, etc.) involving a lot of difficulty and extreme or strong emotions

meanings: (used about a theory, opinion, etc.) able to be defended against attack or criticism
(used about a job in a university) that can be held for a particular period of time

the tenable theory that a giant meteor strike set off a chain of events resulting in the demise of the dinosaurs
acts that are transgressions against the laws of civilized societies everywhere
a dying woman asking for divine forgiveness for a lifetime of transgressions

meanings: (used especially about a man) good at knowing what to say and how to behave in social situations; appearing relaxed and confident

meanings: the appearance or quality of seeming to be true or real

meanings: to make something less effective; to spoil something

believed that luxury vitiates even the most principled person
